mw_today: Mostly cloudy, with a high near 37. Wind chill values as low as zero. Light south wind increasing to 5 to 9 mph in the morning.
mw_tonight: Isolated snow showers after 3am.  Mostly cloudy, with a low around 18. South southeast wind 3 to 8 mph.  Chance of precipitation is 20%.
btac_hazard: Every time we get to enter the backcountry, it is the chance to view our surroundings with a child-like curiosity.  When it all boils down to it, skiing or sledding is a chance to play outside with our friends and be in a phenomenally interesting compound (snow) that is in a constant state of change. As you move through the mountains, take the time to observe the nature of the snow you are traveling through. How has the wind reshaped the snowpack overnight, and why does the snow you are moving through feel and look like it does? Look for areas where the wind has scoured down and revealed old ski and sled tracks underneath. Is yesterday's track now nowhere to be found due to winds continuing to move snow? This process of observation is one of the most powerful tools in our safe backcountry travel in our toolkit. It is also what enables us to sniff out areas with good, stable skiing and riding, and makes us masters of our own exposure to hazards. There is always something new (and usually something older to track) in the world of snow, we just have to choose to look.
btac_weatherdisc:
Yesterday saw mostly clear skies and colder temperatures with high diffuse clouds in the alpine. Gusts were southwesterly in the 35 mph range and ridgelines at 10,000' saw consistent wind in the teens mph. Light winds are expected today from the S/SW, shifting SE into tomorrow.

Today, dry weather will persist until Wednesday morning. Skies are expected to remain overcast but may break down midday allowing some sunshine through. Temperatures are expected to remain below normal, with highs in the 20s deg F and warming into Wednesday's incoming southwest flow. Yet another pulse of active weather and Pacific moisture is headed our way from Wednesday-Friday, with accumulations of 6 inches expected in the mountains, and rain at lower elevations.
btac_bottomline: Avoid steep slopes where you find evidence of windblown snow. Slides could also break into buried weak layers, producing a more dangerous avalanche. These are most likely above 9,000 feet and could be triggered remotely—from gentler terrain below, above, and to the sides of steep slopes. Be alert to the consequences of being caught in an avalanche in the terrain you are traveling in.
legecast: 6 AM: Up and at em' Jackson Hole. Percolate those coffee beans and prepare to be captivated by edge-created smokescreens. Today we'll be kicking up the crystals from a cornucopia of conditions that defy all definitions. That's because we're set up for a transitional weather day here in the Tetons, as partly cloudy skies become mostly cloudy by the afternoon, potentially producing a stray mountain snow shower or two. Chilly morning temperatures will eventually rise to the mid 20's at the summit and the mid 30's down in the Village. Look for the winds to swing towards the Southwest as they clock in between 10-20mph. Come on out and take some desperately needed time for yourself, because conditions like these are coming straight off the top-shelf. -Lege
gt_detail:
There is a small break between storm cycles. Today, expect partly cloudy skies and temperatures in the mid 20's. Another storm is arriving later this week, so enjoy the calm weather while you can!
After reconciling snowfall data from Grand Targhee Ski Patrol and the Bridger-Teton Avalanche Center, Targhee has revised our total season snowfall to 546&quot.
Sierra_weatherdisc: The forecast calls for slightly warmer, albeit still below-average, temperatures today. Cloud cover and SW winds should increase ahead of the winter storm expected to hit the region tonight through Wednesday. Snowfall may start tonight and become more intense when the main part of the storm arrives tomorrow. Expect continuous snow and strong SW winds all day tomorrow. By Wednesday, the snow should become more showery as the main focus of the storm moves on. Currently, the weather service forecasts 1 to 2 feet of new snow above 7000 ft by Wednesday afternoon, with some areas getting closer to 30 inches.
Sierra_btmline:
Triggering an avalanche remains possible today. Watch out for areas where wind-blown snow has piled up on open slopes near ridges, gullies, and below cornices. Weak snow may still linger on steep slopes in cold, sheltered areas. If you see signs of unstable snow, move to terrain not steep enough for snow to slide downhill.

The avalanche danger will increase tomorrow as a winter storm impacts the area.
Sierra_hazard_disc:
• Ski cuts above a test slope on Carson Pass yesterday triggered a wider-than-expected wind slab failure in the test slope. Another test slope in that area did not break as wide. In the Incline Lake Peak area, ski cuts and tests on wind-loaded test slopes did not produce signs of instability. 
  • Ski cuts on a sheltered N-facing test slope that had previously avalanched caused yesterday's fresh snow to sluff off the firm snow below it on Incline Lake Peak. 
  • While some small rollerballs or pinwheels may form on sunny slopes today, unseasonably cold weather and increased cloud cover this afternoon should prevent widespread wet snow from forming despite the intense spring sun. Sun crusts may exist on sun-exposed E-SE-S-SW-W aspects.
  • No new surface hoar related avalanches have been reported since Monday, and tests targeting this layer indicate that it has gone dormant.
  • The layers in the upper snowpack have started adjusting to the current load, but an additional load tomorrow may reactivate some of these weaknesses.
UT_btmline: Areas of CONSIDERABLE avalanche danger exist on steep wind drifted slopes.  This danger will be most pronounced on upper elevation northwest to east to southeast facing terrain.  A MODERATE danger exists for triggering soft slab avalanches 1-2' deep on all other aspects and elevations.  Natural cornice fall and roof-alanches are likely today.  Pay close attention to the sun and warming temperatures.  The wet avalanche danger may rapidly increase today on all solar aspects and even low elevation northerly slopes.
UT_avyconditions: Skies are partly cloudy.  Mountain temperatures are in the teens.  Winds, again, play the spoiler.  Ahead of this next Pacific storm, winds out of the southwest have increased, blowing 25-30mph with gusts to 40.  The highest ridgelines are gusting to near 70mph. For today we'll have periods of sun with alternating high and mid-level clouds drifting through.  Mountain temperatures rise into the mid-20s up high, the mid-30s (or more) down low.  Winds will be moderate to strong out of the southwest.  Wind and sun damage now exist in exposed terrain, but soft settled powder can be found in the sheltered shady slopes. The Outlook: Yet another powerful Pacific storm is on deck.  We'll see increasing clouds and southwest winds today, tonight and tomorrow ahead of at-times heavy snowfall Wednesday night through Friday.  1-2' of new snow may be expected.
UT_recentactivity: High snowfall rates and moderate to strong west to northwest wind led to natural avalanches in the new snow yesterday morning.  The most significant avalanches we heard about include White Pine Chute and Red Top (Long John Silver - pic 1) in Little Cottonwood Canyon, and a natural soft slab avalanche on the northwestern flank of Box Elder Peak (pic 2).
solitude_detail: Believe it or not, we're expecting mostly sunny conditions today! Temps will be warmer than they have been with a high around 34 today. It should be a good day to shed a layer and bring out the dark lenses. Patrol has been using this break in the weather to drop ropes all around the mountain, with all of Honeycomb Canyon and Evergreen Peak open as of yesterday. The skiing and riding has been phenomenal after picking up 69 inches in the past week - bringing us to a record-breaking season total of 705 inches! The snow isn't over yet though - we're eying another storm that is due to hit late Wednesday, adding to our already deep snowpack as we get into the spring season. As usual, keep an eye on the Solitude app for the latest updates on lift and terrain status, events, and hours of operation!
